text: THE PREFACE
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The artist is the creator of beautiful things.  To reveal art and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: conceal the artist is art's aim.  The critic is he who can translate
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: into another manner or a new material his impression of beautiful
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: things.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The highest as the lowest form of criticism is a mode of autobiography.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Those who find ugly meanings in beautiful things are corrupt without
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: being charming.  This is a fault.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Those who find beautiful meanings in beautiful things are the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: cultivated.  For these there is hope.  They are the elect to whom
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: beautiful things mean only beauty.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: There is no such thing as a moral or an immoral book.  Books are well
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: written, or badly written.  That is all.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The nineteenth century dislike of realism is the rage of Caliban seeing
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: his own face in a glass.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The nineteenth century dislike of romanticism is the rage of Caliban
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: not seeing his own face in a glass.  The moral life of man forms part
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of the subject-matter of the artist, but the morality of art consists
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: in the perfect use of an imperfect medium.  No artist desires to prove
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: anything.  Even things that are true can be proved.  No artist has
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: ethical sympathies.  An ethical sympathy in an artist is an
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: unpardonable mannerism of style.  No artist is ever morbid.  The artist
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: can express everything.  Thought and language are to the artist
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: instruments of an art.  Vice and virtue are to the artist materials for
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: an art.  From the point of view of form, the type of all the arts is
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: the art of the musician.  From the point of view of feeling, the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: actor's craft is the type.  All art is at once surface and symbol.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Those who go beneath the surface do so at their peril.  Those who read
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: the symbol do so at their peril.  It is the spectator, and not life,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that art really mirrors.  Diversity of opinion about a work of art
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: shows that the work is new, complex, and vital.  When critics disagree,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: the artist is in accord with himself.  We can forgive a man for making
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: a useful thing as long as he does not admire it.  The only excuse for
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: making a useless thing is that one admires it intensely.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: All art is quite useless.

text: "And much less than a friend.  A sort of brother, I suppose?"

text: "Oh, brothers!  I don't care for brothers.  My elder brother won't die,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and my younger brothers seem never to do anything else."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Harry!" exclaimed Hallward, frowning.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "My dear fellow, I am not quite serious.  But I can't help detesting my
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: relations.  I suppose it comes from the fact that none of us can stand
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: other people having the same faults as ourselves.  I quite sympathize
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: with the rage of the English democracy against what they call the vices
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of the upper orders.  The masses feel that drunkenness, stupidity, and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: immorality should be their own special property, and that if any one of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: us makes an ass of himself, he is poaching on their preserves.  When
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: poor Southwark got into the divorce court, their indignation was quite
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: magnificent.  And yet I don't suppose that ten per cent of the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: proletariat live correctly."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "I don't agree with a single word that you have said, and, what is
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: more, Harry, I feel sure you don't either."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Lord Henry stroked his pointed brown beard and tapped the toe of his
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: patent-leather boot with a tasselled ebony cane.  "How English you are
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Basil!  That is the second time you have made that observation.  If one
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: puts forward an idea to a true Englishman--always a rash thing to
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: do--he never dreams of considering whether the idea is right or wrong.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The only thing he considers of any importance is whether one believes
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: it oneself.  Now, the value of an idea has nothing whatsoever to do
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: with the sincerity of the man who expresses it.  Indeed, the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: probabilities are that the more insincere the man is, the more purely
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: intellectual will the idea be, as in that case it will not be coloured
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: by either his wants, his desires, or his prejudices.  However, I don't
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: propose to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you.  I
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: like persons better than principles, and I like persons with no
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: principles better than anything else in the world.  Tell me more about
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Mr. Dorian Gray.  How often do you see him?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Every day.  I couldn't be happy if I didn't see him every day.  He is
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: absolutely necessary to me."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "How extraordinary!  I thought you would never care for anything but
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: your art."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "He is all my art to me now," said the painter gravely.  "I sometimes
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: think, Harry, that there are only two eras of any importance in the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: world's history.  The first is the appearance of a new medium for art,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art also.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: What the invention of oil-painting was to the Venetians, the face of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Antinous was to late Greek sculpture, and the face of Dorian Gray will
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: some day be to me.  It is not merely that I paint from him, draw from
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: him, sketch from him.  Of course, I have done all that.  But he is much
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: more to me than a model or a sitter.  I won't tell you that I am
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: dissatisfied with what I have done of him, or that his beauty is such
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that art cannot express it.  There is nothing that art cannot express,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and I know that the work I have done, since I met Dorian Gray, is good
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: work, is the best work of my life.  But in some curious way--I wonder
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: will you understand me?--his personality has suggested to me an
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: entirely new manner in art, an entirely new mode of style.  I see
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: things differently, I think of them differently.  I can now recreate
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: life in a way that was hidden from me before.  'A dream of form in days
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of thought'--who is it who says that?  I forget; but it is what Dorian
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Gray has been to me.  The merely visible presence of this lad--for he
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: seems to me little more than a lad, though he is really over
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: twenty--his merely visible presence--ah!  I wonder can you realize all
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that that means?  Unconsciously he defines for me the lines of a fresh
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: school, a school that is to have in it all the passion of the romantic
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: spirit, all the perfection of the spirit that is Greek.  The harmony of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: soul and body--how much that is!  We in our madness have separated the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, an ideality that is
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: void.  Harry! if you only knew what Dorian Gray is to me!  You remember
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me such a huge price
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: but which I would not part with?  It is one of the best things I have
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: ever done.  And why is it so?  Because, while I was painting it, Dorian
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Gray sat beside me.  Some subtle influence passed from him to me, and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: for the first time in my life I saw in the plain woodland the wonder I
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: had always looked for and always missed."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Basil, this is extraordinary!  I must see Dorian Gray."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Hallward got up from the seat and walked up and down the garden.  After
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: some time he came back.  "Harry," he said, "Dorian Gray is to me simply
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: a motive in art.  You might see nothing in him.  I see everything in
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: him.  He is never more present in my work than when no image of him is
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: there.  He is a suggestion, as I have said, of a new manner.  I find
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: him in the curves of certain lines, in the loveliness and subtleties of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: certain colours.  That is all."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Then why won't you exhibit his portrait?" asked Lord Henry.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Because, without intending it, I have put into it some expression of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: all this curious artistic idolatry, of which, of course, I have never
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: cared to speak to him.  He knows nothing about it.  He shall never know
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: anything about it.  But the world might guess it, and I will not bare
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: my soul to their shallow prying eyes.  My heart shall never be put
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: under their microscope.  There is too much of myself in the thing,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Harry--too much of myself!"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Poets are not so scrupulous as you are.  They know how useful passion
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: is for publication.  Nowadays a broken heart will run to many editions."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "I hate them for it," cried Hallward.  "An artist should create
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: beautiful things, but should put nothing of his own life into them.  We
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: live in an age when men treat art as if it were meant to be a form of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: autobiography.  We have lost the abstract sense of beauty.  Some day I
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: will show the world what it is; and for that reason the world shall
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: never see my portrait of Dorian Gray."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "I think you are wrong, Basil, but I won't argue with you.  It is only
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: the intellectually lost who ever argue.  Tell me, is Dorian Gray very
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: fond of you?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: The painter considered for a few moments.  "He likes me," he answered
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: after a pause; "I know he likes me.  Of course I flatter him
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: dreadfully.  I find a strange pleasure in saying things to him that I
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: know I shall be sorry for having said.  As a rule, he is charming to
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: me, and we sit in the studio and talk of a thousand things.  Now and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: then, however, he is horribly thoughtless, and seems to take a real
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: delight in giving me pain.  Then I feel, Harry, that I have given away
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: my whole soul to some one who treats it as if it were a flower to put
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: in his coat, a bit of decoration to charm his vanity, an ornament for a
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: summer's day."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Days in summer, Basil, are apt to linger," murmured Lord Henry.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Perhaps you will tire sooner than he will.  It is a sad thing to think
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of, but there is no doubt that genius lasts longer than beauty.  That
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: accounts for the fact that we all take such pains to over-educate
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: ourselves.  In the wild struggle for existence, we want to have
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: something that endures, and so we fill our minds with rubbish and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: facts, in the silly hope of keeping our place.  The thoroughly
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: well-informed man--that is the modern ideal.  And the mind of the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: thoroughly well-informed man is a dreadful thing.  It is like a
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: _bric-a-brac_ shop, all monsters and dust, with everything priced above
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: its proper value.  I think you will tire first, all the same.  Some day
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: you will look at your friend, and he will seem to you to be a little
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: out of drawing, or you won't like his tone of colour, or something.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: You will bitterly reproach him in your own heart, and seriously think
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that he has behaved very badly to you.  The next time he calls, you
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: will be perfectly cold and indifferent.  It will be a great pity, for
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: it will alter you.  What you have told me is quite a romance, a romance
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of art one might call it, and the worst of having a romance of any kind
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: is that it leaves one so unromantic."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Harry, don't talk like that.  As long as I live, the personality of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Dorian Gray will dominate me.  You can't feel what I feel.  You change
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: too often."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Ah, my dear Basil, that is exactly why I can feel it.  Those who are
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: faithful know only the trivial side of love: it is the faithless who
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: know love's tragedies."  And Lord Henry struck a light on a dainty
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with a self-conscious and
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: satisfied air, as if he had summed up the world in a phrase.  There was
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: a rustle of chirruping sparrows in the green lacquer leaves of the ivy,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and the blue cloud-shadows chased themselves across the grass like
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: swallows.  How pleasant it was in the garden!  And how delightful other
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: people's emotions were!--much more delightful than their ideas, it
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: seemed to him.  One's own soul, and the passions of one's
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: friends--those were the fascinating things in life.  He pictured to
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: himself with silent amusement the tedious luncheon that he had missed
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: by staying so long with Basil Hallward.  Had he gone to his aunt's, he
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: would have been sure to have met Lord Goodbody there, and the whole
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: conversation would have been about the feeding of the poor and the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: necessity for model lodging-houses. Each class would have preached the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: importance of those virtues, for whose exercise there was no necessity
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: in their own lives.  The rich would have spoken on the value of thrift,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and the idle grown eloquent over the dignity of labour.  It was
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: charming to have escaped all that!  As he thought of his aunt, an idea
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: seemed to strike him.  He turned to Hallward and said, "My dear fellow,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: I have just remembered."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Remembered what, Harry?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Where I heard the name of Dorian Gray."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Where was it?" asked Hallward, with a slight frown.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "Don't look so angry, Basil.  It was at my aunt, Lady Agatha's.  She
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: told me she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray.  I am bound to
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: state that she never told me he was good-looking. Women have no
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: appreciation of good looks; at least, good women have not.  She said
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: that he was very earnest and had a beautiful nature.  I at once
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: pictured to myself a creature with spectacles and lank hair, horribly
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: freckled, and tramping about on huge feet.  I wish I had known it was
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: your friend."
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "I am very glad you didn't, Harry."

text: "Why?"

text: "You don't want me to meet him?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "No."

text: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir," said the butler, coming into
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: the garden.

text: "You must introduce me now," cried Lord Henry, laughing.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: with his finely curved scarlet lips, his frank blue eyes, his crisp
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: he asked.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of us is here for.  People are afraid of themselves, nowadays.  They
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: of society, which is the basis of morals, the terror of God, which is

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: It was on the ninth of November, the eve of his own thirty-eighth
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: birthday, as he often remembered afterwards.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: and foggy.  At the corner of Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street,
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: a man passed him in the mist, walking very fast and with the collar of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: his grey ulster turned up.  He had a bag in his hand.  Dorian
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: recognized him.  It was Basil Hallward.  A strange sense of fear, for
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: which he could not account, came over him.  He made no sign of
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: recognition and went on quickly in the direction of his own house.
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: But Hallward had seen him.  Dorian heard him first stopping on the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: on his arm.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: you in your library ever since nine o'clock. Finally I took pity on
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: you passed me.  But I wasn't quite sure.  Didn't you recognize me?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Square.  I believe my house is somewhere about here, but I don't feel
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: seen you for ages.  But I suppose you will be back soon?"
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: "No:  I am going to be out of England for six months.  I intend to take
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: a studio in Paris and shut myself up till I have finished a great
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: talk.  Here we are at your door.  Let me come in for a moment.  I have

text: something to say to you."

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: That evening, at eight-thirty, exquisitely dressed and wearing a large
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: Narborough's drawing-room by bowing servants.  His forehead was
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: manner as he bent over his hostess's hand was as easy and graceful as
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: ever.  Perhaps one never seems so much at one's ease as when one has to
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: play a part.  Certainly no one looking at Dorian Gray that night could
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: have believed that he had passed through a tragedy as horrible as any
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: tragedy of our age.  Those finely shaped fingers could never have
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: clutched a knife for sin, nor those smiling lips have cried out on God

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: double life.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: was a very clever woman with what Lord Henry used to describe as the
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

text: remains of really remarkable ugliness.  She had proved an excellent
title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
